H0.text: Electrical is the type of chemical process most likely that occurred when students added sodium hydroxide crystals to a beaker of water and allowed the resulting solution to cool.

H1.text: Energetic is the type of chemical process most likely to have occurred when students added sodium hydroxide crystals to a beaker of water and allowed the resulting solution to cool.

H2.text: Exothermic is the type of chemical process that most likely occurred when students added sodium hydroxide crystals to a beaker of water and allowed the resulting solution to cool.

H3.text: Endothermic is the type of chemical process that most likely occurred when students added sodium hydroxide crystals to a beaker of water and allowed the resulting solution to cool.

A4.text: The opposite is an endothermic reaction, which usually takes up heat and is driven by an entropy increase in the system.

A5.text: In an exothermic reaction, by definition, the enthalpy change has a negative value: Î”H = Hproducts - Hreactants < 0

A6.text: Once initiated, the exothermic transformation is complete in a few minutes, with a 6.5% increase in volume of the solid.
